Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Gene flow by seed and pollen: implications for plant adaptation to changing climates
Award.AbstractNarration:
A critical challenge for ecologists today is to understand how species will respond to projected shifts in climate. Particularly lacking are approaches considering how genetic connectivity among populations will influence local adaptation to novel climates. In flowering plants, gene flow occurs through seed dispersal and pollen movement, and these processes can have different consequences for the distribution of genetic variation in traits that determine climatic tolerances. This project will incorporate estimates of seed and pollen movement into an analysis of local adaptation in Lasthenia fremontii (Asteraceae), a plant species that is endemic to vernal pool wetlands of western North America. The distribution of genetic variation, due to seed versus pollen movement, will be analyzed across the species range using molecular markers. This analysis will make it possible to evaluate the consequences of gene flow on the potential for plant populations to adapt to changing climate conditions.

Climate change presents a major threat to the world?s biodiversity. Species with patchy distributions, fragmented habitats and limited dispersal abilities, including many rare plant species, are particularly vulnerable because they cannot shift their distributions to track changing climatic regimes. Our project will significantly contribute to restoration and conservation efforts for narrowly distributed plant species in the face of climate change. We will develop a practical guide for the study of population genetics in vernal pool plant species that will be distributed to state and federal agencies, research institutes, and non-profit organizations involved in the conservation and management of vernal pool ecosystems. In addition, the project will provide research experience to undergraduate students, including individuals from groups underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change presents a major threat to the world’s biodiversity. Species that depend on habitats that are naturally patchy or recently fragmented, including many rare and endemic plant species, have a limited ability to disperse and track their optimal climate conditions as temperature and precipitation patterns shift across landscapes. The persistence of these species may be particularly dependent on their potential to evolve to adapt to the new climatic conditions that develop in their current locations. The amount of genetic variation within a population, and the extent to which genes move among populations, play key roles in determining the potential for a population to evolve in response to changing conditions. The goal of this project was to quantify the processes that shape the distribution of genetic variation within and among plant populations that are under strong pressure for rapid evolutionary responses to climate change.

Flowering plant species have two mechanisms for moving genes through space: pollen and seed dispersal. While both of these processes distribute genetic variation within and among populations, they differ in ways that have important evolutionary consequences. Most notably, one seed can move twice the number of copies of a gene compared to an individual pollen grain, thus a dispersing seed has the ability to introduce more genetic variation into a new population than a pollen grain from the same individual. On the other hand, genes that are introduced into a new population through pollen can immediately lead to novel combinations of genes when fertilization occurs, while these combinations would require at least one full generation to develop following gene movement by seed. Thus, the relative importance of pollen and seed movement in shaping the distribution of genetic variation among populations is unclear, raising the opportunity for empirical studies to inform our understanding of these processes.

This project analyzed the relative contributions of seed and pollen movement to the overall distribution of genetic variation in Lasthenia fremontii (Asteraceae), an annual plant species that is endemic to vernal pool wetlands of western North America. Vernal pools function like islands in an archipelago, with individual pools clustering into small groups (complexes) that are scattered throughout the California Floristic Province. The mediterranean climate of the region (cool, wet winters, followed by hot, dry summers) drives seasonal cycles of flooding and drought in these wetlands, which support a diverse community of plants that are adapted to these unique, extreme conditions and that are expected to be highly sensitive to climate change. This research used recently-developed molecular markers for Lasthenia fremontii that are passed from parent to offspring by seed only (chloroplast markers) or by both seed and pollen (nuclear markers) to measure the relative importance of seed and pollen movement in connecting populations that currently experience different climatic conditions. This approach revealed pollen is the main driver of gene movement among pools that are in close proximity to one another (within the same complex), but that neither seeds nor pollen show much movement across broad geographic scales (among complexes). The limited movement of pollen and seeds across large distances causes many populations in different complexes to be genetically isolated from one another, limiting their potential to exchange genes that could facilitate their evolutionary responses to climate change. These results also suggest that different populations will exhibit unique responses to climate change because they are not linked through a shared gene pool.

The development of this research project directly contributed to the education and training of the Latina graduate student investigator on this project, Lorena Torres-Martinez, while providing research experiences for many undergraduate students, including several from underrepresented groups in STEM. The results from this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through publications in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at annual scientific meetings. These results are also being shared with federal and state agencies that are involved in the conservation and management of vernal pool ecosystems.
